ExcelFile.title: ExcelFile
ExcelFile.description: Represents an Excel file that has been imported.

id.description: Unique identifier for the ExcelFile entity.

fileName.description: The name of the imported Excel file.

uploadDate.description: The date and time when the Excel file was uploaded.

ExcelRow.title: ExcelRow
ExcelRow.description: Represents a single row of data from an imported Excel file.

id.description: Unique identifier for the ExcelRow entity.

columnA.description: Data from column A of the Excel file.

columnB.description: Data from column B of the Excel file.

columnC.description: Data from column C of the Excel file.

columnD.description: Data from column D of the Excel file.

columnE.description: Data from column E of the Excel file.

definition.description: Stores Excel file metadata.  Path-based ownership for users. Requires userId and excelFileId parameters.

params.name: userId
params.description: The ID of the user who owns the Excel file.

params.name: excelFileId
params.description: The unique ID of the Excel file.

definition.description: Stores individual rows from an Excel file. Path-based ownership under a specific user and file. Requires userId, excelFileId, and excelRowId parameters.

params.name: userId
params.description: The ID of the user who owns the Excel file and row.

params.name: excelFileId
params.description: The ID of the Excel file to which this row belongs.

params.name: excelRowId
params.description: The unique ID of the Excel row.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to store Excel files and their row data in a user-specific hierarchy. Each user has their own collection of Excel files, and each Excel file contains a subcollection of rows. This structure ensures data isolation and simplifies security rules based on user ownership. The structure uses path-based ownership for ExcelFile and ExcelRow, ensuring clear ownership semantics and enabling straightforward security rules. This inherently provides authorization independence; no `get()` calls are needed to check user ownership. The structure also supports QAPs because listing operations are scoped to the user's files and rows, preventing unauthorized access to other users' data.
